title: Collection agency sued me. I have a summons but there is no court date written on it. I can't find a lawyer. Do I need a lawyer
question: Debt collection summons
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Lawsuits and disputes,Summons and complaint,Fees,Court basics,Default judgment
answers:
You have 30 days to file an "Answer" or another pleading with the court. This may be extended, depending upon the manner of service. If you do not file anything with the court, the plaintiff will apply for entry of default judgment. If the plaintiff does this, there will be no trial or court hearing. The plaintiff will obtain a judgment without the court hearing from you.

If you file proper responsive papers, the court will schedule a Status Conference and encourage both sides to try to settle. If the case does not settle, the court will, at that time, set a trial date.

You should consult a lawyer now. Do not wait until the plaintiff applies for entry of default, or until the eve of trial. Sit down with a lawyer for 30 minutes to review the case and your options.

YOU NEED TO HIRE A LAWYER ASAP. WHO IS SUING YOU? HOW MUCH ARE THEY SUING YOU FOR? WHAT TYPE OF COLLECTION ACCOUNT?

I HANDLE CASES SUCH AS THESE ON A DAILY BASIS.

CALL ME AS I AM WILLING TO DISCUSS POSSIBLE ASSISTANCE.

If you are served with a Summons and Complaint, you should first record the date and manner in which you were served, and then retain a lawyer to file a timely response on your behalf. In most instances, for Superior Court lawsuits, you have 30 days from the date of personal service to respond to the Summons and Complaint.

In the event you absolutely cannot afford an attorney to defend you, you can represent yourself "in pro per". You would file either an Answer or a General Denial, and pay the first appearance filing fee.

The form for the Answer is (Judicial Council Form PLD-C-010):

http://www.courts.ca.gov/documents/pldc010.pdf

The form for the General Denial is (Judicial Council Form PLD-050):

http://www.courts.ca.gov/documents/pld050.pdf


If you cannot afford the first appearance filing fee, you may apply for a fee waiver. See:

http://www.courts.ca.gov/selfhelp-lowcosthelp.htm#fees

You may have defenses that you will waive if not raised. Also, you may have counter claims that you can raise (maybe one of them will even lead to a claim for attorney fees). Check with the court on the date. What you received may have been a courtesy copy.

Although you are not legally required to hire an attorney to defend you in court -- you can represent yourself "in pro per" -- I do suggest you consult ASAP with an debt collections defense attorney in your county. S/he will advise you regarding various options: settlement, bankruptcy, defense of lawsuit, etc.
